rights.title: Know Your Rights
core: You have the right to remain silent
You have the right to refuse a search
You have the right to speak to a lawyer
You have the right to a hearing before a judge
You do not have to sign anything you don't understand

street.title: On the Street
street.say: I am exercising my right to remain silent. I do not consent to a search.
dos: Stay calm and keep your hands visible
Ask if you are free to leave
Provide your name if asked (in some states)
Memorize badge numbers and patrol car numbers
donts: Run away or resist, even if you believe it's unjust
Answer questions about your immigration status

home.title: At Home
home.say: I do not consent to your entry. Please slide the warrant under the door.
dos: Ask to see a warrant signed by a judge
Keep the door closed - speak through it
Read the warrant carefully - check name and address
donts: Open the door unless they have a valid judicial warrant
Sign any documents without a lawyer
Answer questions without an attorney present

checkpoint.title: At Checkpoint
checkpoint.say: I choose to remain silent. Am I free to go?
dos: Slow down and stop at the checkpoint
Keep your hands on the steering wheel
Provide license and registration if asked
donts: Try to turn around or evade the checkpoint
Answer questions about citizenship or immigration status
Consent to a search of your vehicle

workplace.title: At Work
workplace.say: I need to speak with my employer and an attorney before answering questions.
dos: Remain calm and do not run
Ask to see the warrant and what areas it covers
Contact your union representative if you have one
donts: Sign anything without reading and understanding it

remember.title: Remember
remember.description: Anything you say can be used against you. Exercising your rights is not an admission of guilt.
